# Talk about Low Budget Flights

|[![sa2.jpg](https://img.youtube.com/vi/ohm5CVdutrw/0.jpg)](https://youtu.be/ohm5CVdutrw)|
|:--:|
|*It Doesn't Matter - Sonic Adventure 2 [OST]*|

Remember a few days ago when I talked about how Sonic was cool? Not just 90s cool, but *cool* cool? Yeah, this game is what cements that fact for me.

*Sonic Adventure 2*, or *Sonic Adventure 2: Battle* for us Gamecube owning plebs, was Sega's last *hurrah* so-to-speak of putting Sonic on his own flagship console. The Dreamcast may not have sold well, but to its many loyal fans and users, it holds a special place in gaming history. I, however, was not one of these Dreamcasters. And yet...due to Sega's release patterns after the Dreamcast's demise, I can't deny how much it shaped my own gaming career. *Shenmue II*, *Jet Set Radio Future*, and *Sega GT 2002* were all amazing titles that I got to play on other consoles. Despite being ports, they still held a charm that was undeniably unique to the Dreamcast. And yes, among this list of games was *Sonic Adventure* and *Sonic Adventure 2*.

## It all starts with this...A jewel containing the ultimate power...

As I mentioned in my *Jak and Daxter* post, the 200s was an era of transitions. Culture was changing, and the rebellious 90s attitude was dying. In its place, the -- let's call it -- "Hot Topic" scene was taking over. Kids were dying their hair black with red streaks. Goth was becoming culturally cool. "Emo", "edgy" -- whatever you want to call it, this mindset of cool was gradually taking over. Things needed to be darker. Things needed to be more serious. So, how did Sega respond to this culture change after creating essentially the mascot of the 90s?

|[![shadow.jpg](data:image/jpeg;base64,)](https://youtu.be/OxLH0nnUnCY)|
|:--:|
|*Throw It All Away - Sonic Adventure 2 [OST]*|

Shadow the Hedgehog. If Hot Topic was a hedgehog, I'm pretty sure it would like Shadow. But you know...something about it worked. Heck, my nephew, years later, preferred Shadow to Sonic when he started playing the games. However, Shadow wasn't a hit for everyone. For longtime Sonic fans, the character felt like a betrayal of what Sonic was all about. Just where was this series headed?

Let's just get down to it. I **like** Shadow -- in *Sonic Adventure 2*. I think he's been horribly misused in every game afterwards. But his first appearance was iconic. Shadow was Sonic's opposite in almost everyway. Whereas Sonic always looked ahead, constantly running towards new adventures, Shadow was clouded by his past. His eyes were fixated on events long since past. Honestly, this stark difference in the characters makes for the entire rivalry. Which is why when Shadow grows as a character at the end of the game, the rivalry no longer feels authentic. Future games would literally *give Shadow amnesia* just to keep this dynamic between the two going. But when it's all said and done, Shadow was a welcome addition to the cast of Sonic and a very memorable antagonist.

## Gameplay Woes

Unfortunately, while Sonic and Shadow feature some of the best level designs in the franchise, the rest of the cast...well, don't hold up as well. *Sonic Adventure* started the trend of Sega adding additional gameplay gimicks to artificially extend the game's length. I get it; I really do it. Sonic blazes through most of his levels in about 3-4 minutes. Asking $60 for a 40-50 minute game would be ludicrous. So Sega started making additional gameplay styles to compliment the spped-based platofrming. In SA2, this took the form of treasure hunting stages and mech-based stages. Unfortunately, both are slow and tedious. But, I don't hate them. And I certainly don't think they make the game bad. That's ridiculous; the treasure hunting is like a 7/10, and the mech stages are like a 6/10. However, the speed stages are easily a 10/10. Take the average, and that lands SA2 at about an 8/10 -- which is fair in my opinion. 

## Live and Learn

|[![live_and_learn.jpg](data:image/jpeg;base64,)](https://youtu.be/jRESgqJIsoo)|
|:--:|
|*Live & Learn ... Main Theme of ”Sonic Adventure 2”*|

In a lot of ways, you could argue *Sonic Adventure 2* was a battle of cultures. Sonic's optimistic, happy-go-lucky personality versus Shadow's dire outlooks on humanity; Knuckles' serious sense of duty versus Rogue's obsession with jewels; and even Tails' desire to prove himself versus Eggman's "better-than-you" attitude. And I haven't touched on the Chao. The Chaos are so iconic that even decades later, there is still a dedicated online community to raising these adorable creatures.

This game means a lot to me; it may not be the deepest game, but it has deep moments. The final scene with Sonic's bittersweet farewell to Shadow would probably earn a spot on my list of great video game moments. Yes, the story takes itself too seriously, but at least it takes itself seriously! I would love to do a more in-depth analysis of this game in the future; despite arguably better Sonic games releasing, this is the own I keep coming back to.

The game culminates to this beauty of a theme song, "Live and Learn." Honestly, that phrase somehow manages to perfectly describe Sonic and Shadow. On one hand, it represent **a somber acknowledgement of past sins**; the only thing we can do is **live and learn**. Yet, there exists a counter meaning. The phrase can also be seen as a command, a request, a life idealology. **Live and learn what tomorrow holds.** I get it, but it makes sad how this game cemented itself in meme culture. The only enjoyment so many people derive from this game will be laughing at its (admittedly) ridiculous parts. But when you it down and really analyze the game, you can see the heart and soul that Sonic Team poured into what could have very well been the final Sonic the Hedgehog game.
